video.title: In-Depth React Tutorial: Build a Hotel Reservation Site (with Contentful and Netlify)
video.description:
Learn React by building a beach resort website project. The project uses React router for routing, React context API for state management, Contentful headless CMS for data management, and Netlify to host the application.

💻 Setup Files: https://github.com/john-smilga/setup-files-react-beach-resort
💻 Finished Project: https://github.com/john-smilga/react-beach-resort-project

🎥 Tutorial from Coding Addict. Check out the Coding Addict YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/codingaddict

🔗 React Udemy course from Coding Addict:  https://www.udemy.com/react-tutorial-and-projects-course/?couponCode=REACTJSONLYTEN

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Aaron
akindipe john
topLevelComment.text: Given that this video was made 3 years ago, the instructor uses context in class components. This may initially feel convoluting. We're in luck however, as it is now possible in React 18 to use context in functional components. I would recommend trying to do the same in your own project as initiating context in functional components is neater and easier than in class components.

topLevelComment.author: akindipe john
topLevelComment.text:
If you are working on this tutorial and you run into a problem at https://youtu.be/LXJOvkVYQqA?t=2757. Try the following:
1. Go to App.js, move your <Navbar /> inside the router but outside the routes like so:
    <>
    <BrowserRouter>      
    <Navbar />
      <Routes>
        <Route exact path="/" element= {<Home />} /> 
        <Route exact path="/rooms/" element={<Rooms/>}/>
        <Route exact path="/rooms/:slug" element={<SingleRoom />}/>
        <Route path="*" element={<Error />} />
      </Routes>
    </BrowserRouter>
This worked for me after I ran into a little bit of difficulty during the project.

topLevelComment.author: akindipe john
topLevelComment.text:
https://youtu.be/LXJOvkVYQqA?t=1921
Update: August 2022. If you are doing this tutorial at the time of this update, it would be good to realize that some changes have been made to the way react-router-dom is used.
1. Your code may need to look like this to work just as it did in the video:
  <BrowserRouter>
      <Routes>
        <Route exact path="/" element={<Home />}/> 
        <Route exact path="/rooms/" element={<Rooms/>}/>
        <Route exact path="/single-room" element={<SingleRoom />}/>
      </Routes>
    </BrowserRouter>

2 "Switch"  is used in the video, however, "Switch" has been replaced by "Routes" in react-router-dom v6
3 "component" doesn't seem to work (at least not for me). "element" worked instead.
4 The element should be in opening and closing tags.

Compare this code with the code in the video at the referenced time-stamp, you should see the differences and hopefully this helps someone who may be wondering why their code is not working despite following everything exactly as it has been written in the video. Cheers.

topLevelComment.author: irakli
topLevelComment.text:
react-router-dom 6 has no switch instead use path='*' element{<Error />}.     also.
 --------- Index.js ---------
 <Routes>
    <Route path='/' element={<Home/>} />
    <Route path='/rooms' element={<Rooms/>}/>
    <Route path='/rooms/:slug' element={<SingleRoom/>}/>

 --------- App.js ---------

    <Route path='*' element={<Error/>}/>

   </Routes>    <Routert>APP </Router>

topLevelComment.author: Newton Art
topLevelComment.text: Hi guys! At 2:16:00 I'm getting an error saying "rooms" is undefined. I put a console.log with 'rooms' to debug and it seems that on the React lifecycle it renders first with 'undefined' and only after that it renders (2 times) the object with the featured rooms. I'm not sure if it's something to do with the 'componentDidMount' on the context.js or something else changed with React Lifecyles. The problem might be something simpler to be honest. Can someone help me pls?

replies.author: Newton Art
replies.text: @Amir Dawod Yep, I did that by using the spread operator to pass the entire state as shown in the video. The values are passing, but they render on a different cycle (that's what I believe is happening)

topLevelComment.author: Bruno Pires
topLevelComment.text:
I appreciate your effort doing this course, but i got to say.. this is not a good tutorial for the ones who never got in touch with React. I've watched 3 from 5 hours of this course, and this course raised me more questions than answers. Sometimes he uses class components, some others he uses functional components,  and he never bothered explaining why and when using each other. And that's just one of the several questions im having now.. 
In my opinion, this is not a tutorial, this is more like a real time coding video with comments.. 
But thanks for sharing your time and knowledge.

replies.author: Noway1252
replies.text: Usually you'd use class components when you either want to have local state within the component, by using state={example: "just an example"}; or you want to use a life cycle method like componentDidMount() or componentDidUpdate(). This before React hooks wasn't possible for functional components so they didn't have local state or access to the life cycle methods. With react hooks now you can have local state with useState hook and useEffect hook can do what componentDidMount and componentDidUpdate do in class component. I hope this was a bit helpful to you. I like comments like yours because they make me think about what I'm learning so thanks for sharing your thoughts.

topLevelComment.author: Tim
topLevelComment.text:
At 2:21:00 I have tried to add the images to Room.js, however they do not load at all. The error I've received is as follows:
 ./src/components/Room.js
  Line 2:  'Link' is defined but never used            no-unused-vars
  Line 4:  'name' is assigned a value but never used   no-unused-vars
  Line 4:  'slug' is assigned a value but never used   no-unused-vars
  Line 4:  'price' is assigned a value but never used  no-unused-vars

Ive looked online at solutions but i don't understand how resolve this, could someone help?

replies.author: Nick Mitchell
replies.text: For future reference - this is the eslint making sure that you don't have any variables that you never use. For example "name": if you create a variable called name e.g. const name = "hello world";  but never use that in your code, the linter (code quality checker) will complain that yes you have declared name, but never used it. Since it has no purpose, to remove this error, either (1) use the variable or (2) delete it.

topLevelComment.author: Abdoul Diallo
topLevelComment.text: Hello, I configured the .env.development file as you instructed but whenever I restart the server, I get the access error: "Expected parameter accessToken". Is there any dependency that I need to install?

replies.author: Noway1252
replies.text: Even though this is a very late reply to your question but this might help people how are starting with this tutorial now or later. I made the mistake of putting the .env.development file inside the src folder and I got the same error you got. You need to place the .env.development file on the same level as the package.json file.

replies.author: Yivan Rodriguez
replies.text: your problem is in your contentApi, more specifically in your images, some have status "Status: Draft" change it to "Status: Published",  because they arrive as "undefined" to your application and the "map" property cannot map undefined values

replies.author: Olaitan Adesoji
replies.text:
the main issue would be coming from your formatData( ) function.. please kindly do a cross check....
maybe you are not setting the state of featuredRooms in the context correctly...
or maybe in the featuredRoom component, you are not correctly destructuring the featuredRoom from the context...

replies.author: Olaitan Adesoji
replies.text:
hello bro..  do you have the data.js files.. please do a crosscheck to ensure that you are getting the correct data.. also in the context, you need to ensure that you are actually setting the state properly...
for react to say property 0 of undefined, it means that you didnt destructure all the properties of the room from the data.js..
recall that inside the context , you are passing the whole state into the provider.. so inside the featured room component, you can then destructure the needed parameters
i.e {images,loading, /*and so on */} = value...


 before using them in

topLevelComment.author: Pakata Goh
topLevelComment.text: So how did the single room page refresh work? Why didn't it crash

replies.author: Pakata Goh
replies.text: okay. I spoke to a rubber duck and solved it. During a single room page refresh, context.js will run and during componentDidMount, it will fetch the data. Once fetch is completed, it will rerender the single room page again with the fetched data. So for a split second, one would actually see the message that no such room exists. (you can see this by setting some kind of delay during the componentDidMount in context.js)
